description: From mediaeval Latin hypostaticus, from Ancient Greek ὑποστατικός (hupostatikós), from ὑποστατός (hupostatós). Equivalent to hypostasis +‎ -tic.

adjectives.description: hypostatic (comparative more hypostatic, superlative most hypostatic)

entries.meaning: (theology) Pertaining to hypostasis, especially with reference to hypostatic union.
examples: The grand doctrine of the chymists, touching their three hypostatical principles.

entries.meaning: Personal, or distinctly personal; relating to the divine hypostases, or substances.
examples: The hypostatic union , as it is called , the perfect and complete union of two whole and perfect natures in the person of Jesus Christ , underlies this apparent paradox

entries.meaning: (medicine) Pertaining to hypostasis; depending upon, or due to, deposition or setting.
examples: hypostatic congestion, due to setting of blood by gravitation

entries.meaning: (genetics) Of a gene, affected by hypostasis.
